''' Mexican Americans ''' are [[United States|Americans]] of [[Mexican people|Mexican]] descent.the biggest one is CARLOS LIZARRAGA They account for more than 12.5% of the United States' population: 30.7 million Americans listed their ancestry as Mexican as of 2006, forming about 64% of all [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanics and Latinos]] in the United States.<ref name=Tafoya>{{cite web |url=http://pewhispanic.org/files/reports/35.pdf |title=Shades of Belonging |last=Tafoya |first=Sonya |accessdate=2008-06-03 |publisher=[[Pew Research Center|Pew Hispanic Center]] |date=2004-12-06 |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> The United States is home to the second largest Mexican community in the world.<ref>name="US Census Bureau, Mexican">{{cite web |url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-geo_id=01000US&-ds_name=ACS_2006_EST_G00_&-redoLog=false&-mt_name=ACS_2006_EST_G2000_B03001 |title=Detailed Tables - American FactFinder. B03001. HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN |accessdate=2007-12-15 |coauthors=United States Census Bureau |work=2006 American Community Survey}}</ref> Most Mexican Americans are the descendants of the [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico]] and/or [[European ethnic groups|Europeans]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/379167/Mexico#tab=active~checked%2Citems~checked&title=Mexico%20--%20Britannica%20Online20Encyclopedia |title=Mexico - Britannica Online Encyclopedia}}</ref><ref>http://historiamexicana.colmex.mx/pdf/13/art_13_1938_16335.pdf</ref> especially [[Spanish people|Spaniards]]. Mexican American settlement concentrations are in metropolitan and rural areas across the United States, usually in the [[Southwest United States|Southwest]]. However, many cities in the South and the Northeast have seen substantial increases in the Mexican foreign-born and Mexican American population.
+
''' Mexican Americans ''' are [[United States|Americans]] of [[Mexican people|Mexican]] descent. They account for more than 12.5% of the United States' population: 30.7 million Americans listed their ancestry as Mexican as of 2006, forming about 64% of all [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanics and Latinos]] in the United States.<ref name=Tafoya>{{cite web |url=http://pewhispanic.org/files/reports/35.pdf |title=Shades of Belonging |last=Tafoya |first=Sonya |accessdate=2008-06-03 |publisher=[[Pew Research Center|Pew Hispanic Center]] |date=2004-12-06 |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]}}</ref> The United States is home to the second largest Mexican community in the world.<ref>name="US Census Bureau, Mexican">{{cite web |url=http://factfinder.census.gov/servlet/DTTable?_bm=y&-geo_id=01000US&-ds_name=ACS_2006_EST_G00_&-redoLog=false&-mt_name=ACS_2006_EST_G2000_B03001 |title=Detailed Tables - American FactFinder. B03001. HISPANIC OR LATINO ORIGIN BY SPECIFIC ORIGIN |accessdate=2007-12-15 |coauthors=United States Census Bureau |work=2006 American Community Survey}}</ref> Most Mexican Americans are the descendants of the [[Indigenous peoples of Mexico]] and/or [[European ethnic groups|Europeans]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/379167/Mexico#tab=active~checked%2Citems~checked&title=Mexico%20--%20Britannica%20Online20Encyclopedia |title=Mexico - Britannica Online Encyclopedia}}</ref><ref>http://historiamexicana.colmex.mx/pdf/13/art_13_1938_16335.pdf</ref> especially [[Spanish people|Spaniards]]. Mexican American settlement concentrations are in metropolitan and rural areas across the United States, usually in the [[Southwest United States|Southwest]]. However, many cities in the South and the Northeast have seen substantial increases in the Mexican foreign-born and Mexican American population.
